addressleaf.section:
To the right honorable my very singular good Lord,
e L. Burghley Lord highe Treasurer of England.

26 Junij
1592.
M
r
Bodeleie to my L.
The rendringe of
Stenwick.

page.lettertext:
fol.52r
May it please yo
r
good L. I desired a
gentleman one
M
r
Gent
, to whome this mor-
ning I delivered my last to yo
r
L. to signifie
by worde,
at steenwicke was yelded. Whiche
I had not
e leasure, to putte in a letter, because
e bringer of
e newes came but presently then
when he was departing. What was done by o
r
souldiers, before
e towne was given up, yo
r
L.
may see by
e copie of a letter, w
ch
was written
from thens
e self same day in
e morning: w
ch
I
send yo
w
together w
t
e Articles of
e Accord,
at
were concluded then at night. There
were found in
e towne
at marched away 550
souldiers, besides 200 hurt and sicke, and at
the lest 300 slaine. Howbeit it is thought,
that we have lost of o
rs
, sins
e siege beganne
at
e lest a 1000 men: and
at of o
r
Captaines
and principal officers
e greatest part are
hurt and slaine.
W
ch
I thought to advertise
w
t
e rest, and so I take my humble leave.
Fr
o
e Hage. June 26 1592.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden. Tho. Bodley
